channel.title: Ubuntu
channel.description: I have no idea where to post this, so here it is. I installed Ubuntu along side of my other OS, which is Windows Vista. I thought it would be nice to have it when I want to use something different. So I installed it, now when I turn on my computer, I can't connect to the internet. So I get my CD for my wireless card and put it in, and the run is a .exe, big shock. I can't run it on Ubuntu, so I have to install WINE. I can't install it without a connection, so I start up in Windows. I get some weird ass error that none of my drives can be read except the recovery one, X:. So while I'm confused as fuck, I try to use system restore and it didn't work at all. Anyways, I need to know how to uninstall this thing, because it's going to screw up my computer, I think. Someone please tell me what to do. Google tells me to get my Windows Vista installation disk, meanwhile this computer is 4 years old, and I can't remember where I put a CD 4 years ago. I'm not even sure I got one... Okay if you can help me uninstall this thing or help me make it work, I'll love you ;)

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

sarcasm was not detected.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

T4_:

hmmm… installing windows binaries that are drivers via wine seems retarded as fuck.

Doesn’t work all the time anyways lol. My old Dell laptop has to use Wine (so i can install it using the CD) then copy the SYS and INF driver files, uninstall the app. Then I can use NDISWrapper lol. Had to do this twice now, until my provider fucked me with a un-portforwardable modem.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

T4_:

hmmm… installing windows binaries that are drivers via wine seems retarded as fuck.

You shouldn’t. Most drivers have a linux counterpart, and the only reason you should need windows drivers is possibly ndiswrapper.

Read full topic

it will MOST LIKELY fuck shit up.

We are talking about ubuntu, not creepers
[/quote]
Resizing an NTFS file-system is just as dangerous as creepers themselves.[/quote]

Yes, But a NTFS file-system doesnt fuck your house inside and out

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:5, topic:400515”][s]All right I just decided to use Ubuntu, since all of my Windows files are still here ;p…

I lugged my pile of shit downstairs and plugged it into my router. I’m installing Ubuntu 11.04 since my current version is 10.10. … Oh it just popped up that I’m out of disk space. Great…

Ok I need to install Java, if somebody can help me over TV install this & get my server running then that would be great. If you don’t know how, don’t try to help, thanks.[/s]

Never mind, I don’t want to use Ubuntu anymore, it says I’m out of disk space, and without any disk space I can’t run a server.
How can I uninstall this thing without losing all of my files?[/quote]

Move the files to a larger hard drive. Install onto the larger hard drive.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

[s]All right I just decided to use Ubuntu, since all of my Windows files are still here ;p…

I lugged my pile of shit downstairs and plugged it into my router. I’m installing Ubuntu 11.04 since my current version is 10.10. … Oh it just popped up that I’m out of disk space. Great…

Ok I need to install Java, if somebody can help me over TV install this & get my server running then that would be great. If you don’t know how, don’t try to help, thanks.[/s]

Never mind, I don’t want to use Ubuntu anymore, it says I’m out of disk space, and without any disk space I can’t run a server.
How can I uninstall this thing without losing all of my files?

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

If you move/resize the windows partition, chances are the filesystem was corrupted. This has happened to me on multiple occasions. In fact, GParted usually let’s you know that if you resize/move, it will MOST LIKELY fuck shit up.

As for Ubuntu, which release did you install? Ubuntu, and Canonical Ltd. are fairly reliable for having updated drivers. If not, I would go to the manufacturer’s website, see if they have any drivers for Linux. If not, then just download the windows drivers, and use ndiswrapper.

Now you’re probably thinking “How can I download those files if I don’t have any networking drivers?” The answer is simple. Find a computer that does have internet access, go to http://sourceforge.net/projects/ndiswrapper/ and download the source. You should then be able to compile, and install the windows drivers.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

System -> Administration -> Additional drivers

If you temporarily connect to your router via an ethernet cable you will be able to get the wireless driver that you need.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

If you changed the size of an NTFC file system (what windows vista & 7 must be installed on) then it is possible some of the files are currupt. Your best bet is to use a externel HDD and make a backup of all your files you will want to keep. You will also want NDISWrapper as this is a tool to help you use windows wireless drivers under ubuntu.

Download the 64bit or 32bit WINE package from here (you will need to know what version of ubuntu you have intsalled)
http://packages.ubuntu.com/natty/wine1.3

Download NDISWrapper from this page:
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/WifiDocs/Driver/Ndiswrapper

Read full topic
